text:
**
Garbage collection is a ritual that is similar in many developed countries. In most places, it is free to dispose of rubbish. However, if rubbish disposal is free, people will produce too much rubbish. To reduce the amount of rubbish that is produced, people need to be charged for disposing of their waste. This will give them an incentive to throw out less and recycle more.
When a town starts charging for rubbish disposal, the number of bags or cans that are collected usually decreases. However, this is often due to the 'Seattle stomp', which is when people cram more garbage into each container. This can be done better by machines at landfill sites than by individuals.
In addition to the reduction in the number of bags or cans that are collected, there is also an increase in the weight of materials recycled. This is because people are more likely to recycle if they have to pay to dispose of their rubbish.

**
Work can be a rewarding and fulfilling experience, but it can also be stressful and unsatisfying. To be successful in your career, you need to be able to communicate effectively, be creative and imaginative, and be able to work well with others. If you are not able to do these things, no amount of money or status will be able to compensate for your inadequacy as a human being.
There are a number of things that can make work more fulfilling. One is to find a job that you are passionate about. Another is to be able to work in a supportive and collaborative environment. If you are able to do both of these things, you will be much more likely to be successful in your career.
However, there are also a number of challenges that can make work difficult. One is stress. Another is the feeling of being unappreciated or undervalued. If you are experiencing these challenges, it is important to find ways to cope. There are many things that you can do to reduce stress and improve your overall well-being.

Broadcasting is a technology that was originally used to sow seeds broadly. It is also a metaphor for optimistic modernism. It is about planned growth and the production of a rich harvest.
The metaphor presupposes a bucket of seeds at the centre of the activity, which means that there are centralised resources intended for spreading and reproduction.
Since television is related to various two-way forms of communication, it is striking that it was envisaged as a centralised 'mass' medium. However, transmission to private homes from some centralised unit was simply in keeping with both socio-economic structures and the dominant ways of life in modern and modernising societies.
In the early 1930s, there were attempts to experiment with other forms of organisation. But these attempts remained just that - attempts and experiments.
Television was also primarily a medium for theatrical exhibition in the USA in the early 1930s. And as such often thought to be a potential competitor of the film industry.

Sometimes it feels like having a lot of possessions doesn't make you feel secure. It's reasonable to want to have a comfortable home that meets your needs, but there's a point where the desire to acquire things gets out of control. Advertising can be very persuasive, and it can make you feel like you need to buy things you don't have. To see how much you are influenced, I challenge you to not read any advertising billboards next time you go down the street.
Caves are a mysterious part of the natural environment. They have been studied for many years, and there is a lot of research about them. Caves are also important because they have a long history of study. However, exploring caves can be physically demanding, so cave research has been less in the hands of learned professors than other scientific fields.
Meteorology is the study of weather. Countless people have laid the foundations of meteorology, and it has progressed into a highly technical science. Satellites and electronic instruments provide us with a lot of weather information, and computers can solve complex mathematical problems quickly. However, human experience is still the most important part of meteorology. It is the human observations that translate computed data into weather forecasts.

**
Music and theatre are two different art forms. Opera is primarily a theatre performance, but the music comes first. The music is the heart of opera. At a musical performance, there will usually be people who don't understand the technical or academic aspects of music. However, most people are impressed by the skill of the performers. Music and theatre audiences have different expectations. Theatre audiences expect to understand the nature of an actor's skill and be awed by the activity. Music audiences expect to be able to appreciate the beauty and skill of the performers. There are some things that could be done to change the conventions of music-going. For example, music audiences could be more patient and allow the performers to complete their performance without interrupting. They could also be more willing to try new and unfamiliar music.

Sand is a nuisance when it is in its natural state. It blows in your face, gets in your sandwiches, and sticks to you. When you are wet, it adheres to you like 'stucco'. But, when you step onto a beach towel or climb into a car, it pours off you. Sand can stay with you for a long time. It is a nuisance to keep sand away.
A lock and key are used to keep people out of a place. They have been used for a long time. People like locks and keys because they make them feel safe. Some new locking systems use computer cards to control locks. But people don't like them. They prefer to use a physical key.
I was nervous about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery. I didn't understand modern art. But I learned a lot from the labels at the gallery. They helped me understand the art.

Every picture tells a story. Adapting novels for film usually involves reducing, condensing and deleting text. This can be frustrating for the writer, but also illuminating. When I was working on a script, I realized that I could dispense with a lot of the dialogue and narrative description in a given scene, while still getting across the same point.
The studio where I was working was a complex place. It was made up of many different buildings, and it was difficult to find your way around. But the studio lacked a focus. It would have been much better if there had been a single main entrance.
Film-makers are very passionate about their work. They want to make movies and they want to be successful. If ever dreams came true, they did for Rodriguez - and ahead of schedule.

In those days, the council houses in West Earlham stretched all over the city. They were row after row of huddled, dingy dwellings. In the summer, the chemicals from the factory came and hung around the doors and gardens with a smell of sulphur. The most common sight in that part of Norwich early in the morning was a paperboy wrinkling his nose in disgust as he negotiated somebody's front path. Most of this early life I've forgotten. But there is a memory of sitting on a vantage point near an upstairs window and looking at the houses as they faded away into the distance. Later on, there are other phantoms - faces that I can't put names to, my mother ironing towels in the back room of a house that I don't think was ours, snow falling over the turrets of the great mansion at Earlham. My mother was a small, precise and nearly always angry woman. She was the source of whose anger I never quite understood, and consequently couldn't do anything to appease. To particularise, it meant not straying into neighbours' gardens or jeopardising their rose bushes as you walked down the street; it meant sitting for long half-hours in a silent dining room, with your hands folded across your chest, listening to radio programmes that your mother liked. It was a lot of rules. But my mother was determined to teach me to follow them.

I live on Philadelphia Avenue. It is a busy street. There are many houses and stores. I know this side of the street well. I have lived there for many years.
The weather was warm and rainy the day I wrote this. I was swimming in the pool. The rain fell on me and the water splashed. It was a beautiful day.
I also wrote about my dream of swimming through Britain. I want to follow the rain on its journey and rejoin the sea. I want to break free of the frustration of doing lengths. I want to swim in a place where there is mystery and beauty.

Charles Darwin thought that humans have a natural tendency to cry. It is not clear why we cry, but there are a few possible reasons. One reason is that crying can help us to connect with others. It can also be used to express sympathy or sadness. Sometimes, we cry involuntarily when we hear inspiring music or moving speeches. We may also cry when watching a sentimental film. However, the most important reason for crying is its social function. Tears can help us to build trust and social connectedness.

**
The Earth is getting warmer and this is causing a lot of changes to the planet. The changes are affecting plants, animals, water and soils. Humans have learned to use natural resources to our advantage, but any changes to these resources have to be taken seriously.
One of the biggest problems is that we do not understand fully all the processes of the climatic system. Despite this, most people agree that the rate of change will be faster than anything we have previously experienced.
The effects of climate change are already being felt around the world. Some of the changes that are already happening include changes in precipitation patterns, changes in the timing of seasons, and changes in the distribution of plants and animals.
The future effects of climate change are predicted to be even more severe. Some of the predicted effects include rising sea levels, more extreme weather events, and changes to glacial processes.
The consequences of climate change are potentially devastating. They could include increased flooding and inundation, loss of homes and livelihoods, and mass displacement of people.

**
A mission to Mars is planned for a middle-aged, married couple. The mission will last for 501 days and will take the crew to about 160 kilometers above Mars. The spacecraft will use the gravity of Mars to allow it to return to Earth without burning any more fuel. The goal is to be fuel-efficient, as the next launch window when Mars and Earth align again is not until 2031. The mission is ambitious, but it is also important because it will lead to valuable advances for future missions.

Art is a powerful form of human expression that involves the creation and appreciation of aesthetic objects. These objects exist physically and are often identified with the building, book, painting, or statue in which they are housed. However, the actual work of art is what the product does with and in experience. When artistic objects are separated from their original context and operation, they become isolated and difficult to understand. To understand the meaning of artistic products, we must forget them for a time and turn aside from them to have recourse to the ordinary forces and conditions of experience that we do not usually regard as aesthetic. We must arrive at the theory of art by means of a detour. The arts which today have most vitality for the average person are things he or she does not take to be arts.

Lions are powerful animals that live in Africa. They are often seen hunting for food. When lions hunt, they work together as a group. They are very successful at catching their prey.
But lions are not always successful. Sometimes, they spend too much time trying to catch their prey and not enough time protecting their cubs. If an animal is too generous, its companions benefit at its expense.
Researchers have studied lions for many years. They have learned that lions are not always the best at making decisions. Sometimes, they make decisions that are not in their best interest.
As a child, the author was fascinated by stories of the Sibyl. The Sibyl was a mysterious woman who had a lot of wisdom. The author learned from the Sibyl's stories about salesmanship and life.

The early 1990s were a tough time for advertising professionals. There was a recession in business that was longer, deeper and more severe than anyone could have predicted. It affected every single business in the country, including advertising agencies. Many people lost their jobs and homes, and the economy was in a bad state.
However, despite the challenges, the advertising industry continued to grow. Companies started to realize that they needed to make sure their advertising was effective. They wanted to get better strategies, better targeting, better creativity, and better media placement.
The recession also made it difficult to produce effective advertising. There was a lot of controversy over production costs, and people were reluctant to take risks. As a result, many advertising professionals had to revisit Lord Leverhulme's commonplace that only half of their advertising works.
The situation is currently very difficult for advertising professionals. There is a lot of pressure on them to increase the proportion of advertising that works. Help for those who want or need to do just that is far from freely available.

When I was at university, I decided to become a chef. It was an unusual choice, but I was unhappy at university and I wanted to do something that I enjoyed. Cooking was my passion. I started to cook elaborate meals and I felt happy and fulfilled.
I also learned to dive. I asked my swimming instructor to teach me and he gave me some instructions. I practised until I was able to dive on my own. It was a lot of fun.
The traveller is a person who chooses to live in a world that is outside of the ordinary. They are often willing to take risks to experience new things. I think that the traveller is a fascinating person.

Summer promises us two great joys: escaping home and reading books. Books can help us to feel more at home in the world. We can relate our experiences to those described in great books written long ago or in distant lands. In the books of others, we find our own thoughts, embarrassments and dramas. Authors can locate words to depict a situation we thought ourselves alone in feeling, or can express our very own thoughts, but with a clarity and psychological accuracy we could not match.
We feel grateful to these strangers for reminding us of who we are. Through reading and travel, we escape the deadening effect of habit. Our eyes are never more open than during our first few days in a new place. Our mind is like a radar newly attuned to pick up certain objects floating through consciousness. Our attention is drawn to the shades of the sky, to the changeability of a face, to the hypocrisy of a friend, or to a submerged sadness about a situation that we had previously not even known we could feel sad about.

Fashion is often seen as a modern phenomenon that has developed thanks to the growth of capitalism in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Fashion has a long history, and it has become more complex and significant as societies have developed and technology has improved. Today, it is difficult to say exactly what any item of clothing or adornment means. For example, a man's suit can mean different things to different people in different contexts. Writing can be a way to make ends meet, but it is not always easy to get published. To write a novel, you need to be patient and persistent. You also need to be able to juggle part-time jobs and credit cards. If you are a writer, you may be able to find some opportunities to earn money, but you will need to be prepared for the challenges.

Music has had a significant impact on our lives in many ways. In the past, there has been a decline in the performance of live music and the full-time employment opportunities for professional musicians. However, there has also been a widening access to music through technology. Music is often used in major state occasions and provides opportunities for numerous activities, formal and informal. It is also beneficial to the development of skills such as spatial reasoning, social relationships, concentration and focused study habits.
There are a few challenges facing the music profession in the future. One challenge is the need to adapt to the changing landscape of music listening and making. Another challenge is the need to provide more opportunities for people to learn to play instruments. Finally, the music profession needs to work together to raise the profile of music and ensure that it is valued more in society.

The craft of acting can be seen as a derision or contempt by some people. This is often fueled by actors themselves when they are compelled to talk about their craft in interviews. They should give the dancer Pavlova's reply to the man who asked her what she meant when she was dancing: 'If I could tell you,' she said, 'I wouldn't dance it.' Instead, they often fall into ponderous cliches, silly truisms, or into the prurient jaws of the gossip machine.
A review of Hamlet Adrian Lester's Hamlet is poised precariously between boyhood and manhood. His handling of the text and his physical and psychological self-control take him, in one leap, from brilliantly promising to frontline player: an actor with the intelligent confidence to be almost self-effacing.
What is acting? What is behaviour? Is the former an imitation or an evocation of the latter? That is the central question about the life of the theatre. One director's approach to rehearsal is known as 'dropping in'. This procedure goes something like this. The stage manager projects the script onto a screen. The actors sit quietly while someone else is speaking. When it is their turn to speak, they glance off the screen, digest the first phrase, think about what it means to them, wait to find the impulse - the reason to speak - then speak.
The perfect theatre should make you feel as if your presence has made a difference. It's important that the theatre itself creates a relationship between the performer and the audience. The proportions of an auditorium are important. They have to respond to the human voice and the scale of the human body.

Paul Simon's rock and roll in the 1950s was popular among young people and had a lasting impact on the middle class and the middle-aged. It also paved the way for the next generation of rock idols. The music was new and invigorating, and it was listened to by people all over the world. Paul Simon was one of the young people who listened to this music. He was fascinated by the sounds and prepared himself for the next big step in his life, which was to make his own music.
Snow was falling and the ground was slippery. I was walking on the snow and suddenly I slipped and fell into a hole. The snow had formed a roof over the gap between two rocks, and it melted away to leave nothing but a thin crust through which I had plunged. I was shaken and unnerved, but I managed to haul myself out of the hole. I sat back against a tree and took stock of the situation. I had covered a long way, but I knew I had to abandon my plan.

A few days ago, I noticed my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth while trying to look fierce. I was playing with him and asked him about what he remembered about dinosaurs. The answer was not a lot.
There is a new way to learn things called screen learning. One writer tells how he tried out an interactive programme with his son. The father read the words while the son fiddled with the pictures. It is not a good way to learn things.
Television is an impressionistic, suggestive medium. It needs to be mediated. There is nothing wrong with using new technology to teach our children, but there is still a big role for formal education.
Hollywood is a famous town in the United States. It is known for its film-making industry. A lot of people work in Hollywood, but they often live somewhere else.
Photography is an art form that was invented in the nineteenth century. It is a way to capture images. Photographs can be used to interpret the world, to present a vision of nature and its structure, as well as the things and the people in it.
Book illustration is another art form. It is used to illustrate children's books. During the black-and-white era, it was axiomatic that each and every children's book called for some form of illustration.

In the past, there has been a growing awareness that there can be risks associated with sharing information online. Some people have experienced the negative consequences of public check-ins, which are online announcements of your whereabouts. If you share too much information online, people you don't know may be able to find out where you are and potentially harm you.
However, there are also a lot of positive aspects to sharing information online. For example, you can use social media to connect with friends and family, or to share your thoughts and ideas. You can also use social media to learn new things and to stay up-to-date on current events.
There are a few things to keep in mind when sharing information online. First, you should be aware of the potential risks involved. Second, you should be mindful of the information you are sharing. Third, you should be careful about who you share your information with. If you follow these guidelines, you can enjoy the many benefits of sharing information online without experiencing the negative consequences.

Tiredness has become a common condition in modern society. As countries become richer and busier, sleeplessness and anxiety have also increased. Research in the USA has found that a large number of Americans are affected by chronic insomnia. People often cut back on sleep when they are busy. They get up too early to avoid the rush hour.
There are some things that scientists know about human sleep. Humans sleep like other mammals according to a daily cycle. When asleep, humans switch between four different stages of unconsciousness. Dreams occur during the lightest sleep.
However, there are also a lot of theories about what sleep is for. Some people believe that sleep repairs body tissue or restores muscles. Others believe that sleep rests the frontal section of the brain that controls speech and creativity. But all of these theories are not certain.
There are also some things that scientists are not sure about. For example, they are not sure why older people require less sleep. They are also not sure what the purpose of sleep is.

I stood in my designer cowboy boots on the rocks of an old formation in the Arizona desert sand. I wore the whole cowboy outfit, but I was not a cowboy. It was not working. I squinted into the morning sun and looked out at the Arizona mountains. I felt like I was not at home on the range.
There was a cowboy in the luggage hall of Phoenix airport. He was wearing a sweat-stained I-shirt and needed a shave. He caught sight of my boots and moved off out of the door without looking back.
I used to be a racing driver. I loved being a racing driver, but I don't do it any more. I couldn't if I wanted to. I thought about what I could do now. I have time in the morning and I have time in the afternoon. Maybe I could write a book. Or maybe I could paint. But I don't have any ideas. So I just looked up into the sky. No buzzards overhead. Maybe Arizona doesn't have buzzards.

Vancouver is a city in western Canada where many people from all over the world live. It is a beautiful place with a mild climate, a wonderful setting between the ocean and the mountains, and a clean and safe environment. People come to Vancouver for many reasons, including its educational and job opportunities. The city is also a gateway to other places.
Journalists like me are not very good at writing letters. We often write things that we are not going to be paid for. This is because we are always striving to get the greatest possible effect. The real creative artist, who does not consciously work on the effect at all, does not have this problem.
Last week, there was a new supermarket opening in the city. It was a big event with a lot of people. The first five men and women who entered the store would get a bottle of aftershave or flowers. This information spread quickly and people were very excited.

The film Citizen Kane was released in 1941. It was not a commercial success, but it became popular thanks to television. It is the one film that has inspired people to become film-makers. Orson Welles made his first film, Citizen Kane, and it was a success because he had a great team of people working with him.
One day, Dermot and Carmel were talking. Carmel was thinking about what she was going to do that day. She said that she was going to stroll down town and look at the shops. Dermot agreed with her. He said that she was entitled to enjoy herself.
The survey found that job titles cause a lot of problems at work. A lot of people would be willing to give up a pay rise for a better job title. If we are too concerned about job titles, we are in trouble.

I was in Vienna to take photographs. I was there to take pictures for a picture book. The pictures were more than my livelihood. They were part of my life. The way light fell on a surface always tugged at my imagination. The way one picture could capture the essence of a time and place was embedded in my consciousness. One day, I took the perfect photograph. There was always the chance, so long as there was film in my camera. I went freelance after that. It didn't sound bad to me. I was taking photographs and I was being paid to do it. I was in Vienna to take photographs for a picture book. I had been to Vienna for a long weekend with my wife. It had been hot, hectic and none too memorable. I hadn't even taken many photographs. On my own, in a cold hard January, it was going to be different. I knew that the moment I climbed off the shuttle bus from the airport and let my eyes and brain absorb the pinky-grey dome of light over the snow-sugared roofs of the city. I was going to enjoy myself here. I was going to take some great pictures.

Kinetic art is a type of art that is concerned with movement. In the twentieth century, there has been a lot of kinetic art created. The artworks that are made by kinetic artists either move by themselves or investigate the idea of movement.
A new exhibition at the Hayward Gallery in London traces the history of kinetic art. The exhibition includes paintings, drawings, documents, and films on kinetic art. Visitors can enjoy the artworks without having to read a lot of text.
The exhibition is called "Kinetic Art Rejoice." It is a charmingly idiosyncratic investigation into an almost forgotten aspect of the last 60 years. The exhibition is a must-see for anyone interested in art or kinetic art.

Metals were probably discovered by our early ancestors as a result of their desire to adorn themselves. One day, while sitting by the river, one of our ancestors found a shiny yellow pebble that was different from stone. This pebble was attractive, and it soon became a popular material. Copper was also discovered by chance, and people began to use copper tools. Metalworking was added to our ancestors' accomplishments.
St Ives was a quiet town. We walked down a winding lane to the center of town, but there was no one on the streets. The waves crashed over the promenade, and the shutters in every cottage were bolted tight against the wind. We had watched the weather worsen as we arrived in St Ives. The weather was so bad that we decided to cancel our plans.
The problem with studying the past is that it is gone. We cannot test our hypotheses or rewind the tape and watch a replay of the past. However, computer modelling allows us to recreate prehistoric landscapes and environments and populate them with virtual communities. We can establish rules of conduct and replicate social units. Then we can turn down the rainfall or turn up the population and see how this cyber-culture and its artificial people react.

Vervet monkeys Cheney and Seyfarth were studying a group of vervet monkeys. One day, a strange male was hanging around in a neighbouring grove of trees. The stranger was sizing up the group in order to join it. If he succeeded, it was more than likely that the incumbent male would be ousted from his position of privilege. The male used a ploy to keep the stranger away from his group. He gave an alarm call that vervets use to signal the sighting of a leopard nearby. The stranger shot back into the safety of his trees.
A survey found that the cat population of Britain is killing a large number of birds and small mammals each year. The survey found that the cat is a significant predator, but not that it is devastating Britain's bird population.
The buffaloes are a group of animals that live in the marsh. They spend a lot of time wallowing in the water. The buffaloes are very tired and they groan a lot. They spend the day grazing on green shoots.
Picasso was a painter. He painted a fish still life in 1940. The painting is very beautiful. It is not easy to read the painting because Picasso has treated the composition in terms of a flat pattern of overlapping and interlocking transparent planes.

Photography has been used to record all aspects of human life and activity for over a century. It has allowed us to see the fleeting moment and visualize both the vast and the minuscule. Photography has also brought us images from remote areas of the world and distant parts of the solar system. It has provided one of the most important and influential means of expressing the human condition.
The earliest creations of pictorial recording go back as far as the Upper Palaeolithic period of about 35,000 years ago. Pictures seem to be inextricably linked to human culture. Throughout the history of visual representation, questions have been raised about the accuracy and status of the visual image.
Photography has changed radically since its invention in 1839. It has moved into what might be termed 'mythic time' and has passed out of living memory. The passage of time has transformed the photograph from a memory aid into an historical document.

Writing poetry is like playing a game. You need to be spontaneous and creative, but also be aware of the potential risks. If you try to be too perfect, you might end up ruining your work. To write well, you need to read a lot, write a lot, and let your imagination and spirit run free. You can also find inspiration from others. Some people write to express themselves, others write to escape their misery. There are different ways to write, but the most important thing is to find a way that works for you.
In a short story, there is no room for too many characters or long narratives. Flashbacks should be brief and only used if they help the story. Dialogue is more effective than long explanations. You need to keep the action going and make sure that every word counts.
If you want to write a screenplay, you need to understand the game of chess. The more you play, the more you learn. You need to be able to see the big picture and the patterns in the play. And finally, you need to understand how to get your writing and your mind working together.

**
I have never started a novel with more worry. If I call it a novel, it is because I don't know what else to call it. I have a story to tell, but I end neither with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave my reader in the air. This book consists of my memories of a man I knew well, but I have little knowledge of what happened to him between the times I saw him. I could fill in the gaps, but I have no wish to do that. I only want to set down what I know. To save embarrassment to people still living, I have changed the names of the people in the story. The man I am writing about is not famous. It may be that he never will be. It may be that when his life at last comes to an end, he will leave no more trace of his sojourn on earth than a stone thrown into a river leaves on the surface of the water. Then my book, if it is read at all, will be read only for what intrinsic interest it may possess. But it may be that the way of life that he has chosen for himself and the peculiar strength and sweetness of his character may have an ever-growing influence over his fellow men so that, long after his death perhaps, it may be realised that there lived in this age a very remarkable creature.

Poetry recitals are happening all the time. There are different kinds of poetry being written and different ways of presenting and reciting poetry. Some poets write poems that are meant to be read on the page, while others write poems that are meant to be recited aloud. There are also different ways to promote poetry recitals. Some people hold small literary societies in their towns, while others invite poets to read and talk to audiences of students. Poetry recitals can be a lot of fun, but they are not a substitute for reading poetry on the page.

Oral History
The trend of historians using oral evidence has its challenges. It is not always true that someone's testimony is a pure reflection of the past. In an interview, each person is affected by the other person. The historian chooses the informant and decides what to talk about. Even if the historian does not ask any questions and simply listens, the presence of an outsider changes the atmosphere in which the informant recalls the past. The end product is influenced by both the historian's social position and the terms in which he or she has learned to analyze the past. To be a good historian, you must accept responsibility for your part in creating new evidence.
Animal Science
There are two main approaches to studying animals. The physiological approach focuses on how the body works. The whole animal approach studies the behaviour of the intact animal and the factors that affect it. Within the whole animal approach, there are two main types of study: psychology and ethology. Psychologists study learning abilities in a restricted range of species. Ethologists study naturally occurring, unlearnt behaviour of animals. Although there is some overlap, the two approaches are distinct. To understand animal behaviour, you need to study it at both a physiological and a behavioural level.
The Social Sciences
Studying a social science for the first time can be challenging. You must learn the substance of the subject and the methodology. This means becoming familiar with the knowledge and research findings in the textbooks and the methods used to obtain and organize that knowledge. The two elements are closely related. Although common sense may seem to apply to social life, each social science discipline goes beyond common sense understanding. Each discipline focuses on a particular aspect of social life and uses its own set of concepts. To understand social science, you need to learn the basic ideas in the subject.
Classical Architecture
Classical architecture was more than just the construction of buildings. It was an art form. Vitruvius, a Roman architect, said that architecture consists of order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, propriety, and distribution. These concepts are based on earlier Greek authority. The origins of classical architecture are complex. There was a long history of basic construction before the development of sophisticated architectural concepts. However, the classical temple is a simple, single-roomed hut.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept a secret from Chen for a long time. They would drive around the allotments and the railway line and gasworks, shooting the tiny hump-backed bridge with all four wheels in the air. Chen was amused by what his wife had been doing behind his back. He was happy that Lily had mastered this new skill.
They decided to go on a journey together. They fixed on a Monday at the beginning of next month. They left early in the morning and returned by midday. Lily drove impeccably. She overtook a couple of laggard vehicles with immense verve. Chen went as far as applauding.
They parked in a small street off the sea front. Lily was unclear about the meanings of the various roadmarkings. She preferred to pay a fee rather than risk being towed away.
The end.

I had read somewhere that if you dig a deep hole, you can see the stars. I had invited you to help me with my plan. I climbed down the well and fell into it. I cracked my head and was dazed. I saw lights that were strange and inchoate. I was frightened and relieved. I was angry at you for letting me fall and afraid of what Mother would say. I called out for help, but nobody heard me. I lay still, waiting for help. Finally, I was pulled out of the well. I was tired and scared. I ran away from the well and hid in the shadows. My mother and father came to see me. They were worried about me. I felt ashamed of myself. I knew that I had done something wrong. I apologized to my parents, but they were not happy. They said that I was being ridiculous. They walked away. I was alone and sad. I felt like I had lost everything.

Susan was widowed and her children were grown up. She was leaving her family home. The removers were removing everything from the house. The piano was the most important thing to her. It was a lovely house that she was leaving. The years she had spent there were hanging around in the air.
The removers were taking the piano away. They were struggling to get it out of the house. It was stuck on the stairs. The team of removal men worked for hours to get it out. Finally, they got it down and put it in the van.
The piano was in the sitting room. It was the best room in the house. They would leave it till last. Susan was sad that she was leaving her house. She was going to have to find a new place to live.

The internet opened up a new way for people to share their opinions about books. A popular online bookstore called Amazon allowed anyone to write a review of a book. This made it easy for people to see what others thought of a book. The reviews on Amazon were free and uncensored, which meant that anyone could say what they wanted about a book. However, there were some problems with the reviews. For example, some people wrote fake reviews to promote their own books. And, some people wrote reviews that were too long or too short. Despite these problems, the reviews on Amazon were still a valuable tool for readers. They provided a remarkably accurate indication of whether or not a particular book was worth buying.

Art has changed a lot in the last two hundred years. In the past, art was praised for being unique and revolutionary. Today, we often get cold feet and say that an artist has gone too far. We expect artists to be separate from the rest of us and to have special talents and drive.
There is a new situation that I want to talk about. An artist chooses a piece of text and asks someone to write it on a canvas. The finished product is a painting. But the problem is that the art-buying public often expects artists to stick to one genre. If an artist tries to do something new, they are often met with indignation and the feeling that the artist has let the public down.
I have escaped to this island with a few books. I am quite alone. I lie suspended like a hair or a feather in the cloudy mixtures of memory. The solace of such work as I do with brain and heart lies in this - that only there, in the silences of the painter or the writer can reality be reordered, reworked and made to show its significant side.

My father collected me and my trunk from my posh school and sat through Parent's Day. He had a long conversation with my headteacher and was on his way to London. He said that I could not fool him and that I would do what I wanted. He also said that I had the right sort of personality and that I could pick the bones out of a mass of material pretty quickly. I felt scared and helpless. I knew that I had to do what he said, even if I didn't want to. I was afraid of upsetting him. I was the favourite, but I found him formidable. I lent a hand to my father and was able to get a good education and a good life.

Simon Costello knew that the purchase of the house in Pembroke Square had been a mistake. It was a possession which could only be afforded by exercising stringent and calculated economy. At the time, it had seemed like a sensible and desirable move. He had had a run of successful cases and they were coming in with reassuring regularity. Lois had returned to her job at the advertising agency within two months of the birth of the twins, and had been given a rise which took her salary to thirty-five thousand.
The house wasn't really suitable for a family, and they needed more room, a garden, separate accommodation for an au pair. All these could have been achieved in a suburb or in a less fashionable part of London than Pembroke Square, but Lois was ambitious for more than additional space. The overcrowded tube journey had become an unproductive thirty minutes of brooding on present discontents. He remembered his grandfather's house in Hampstead where he had stayed as a boy, and the smell of dinner from the kitchen.
The job was important to Lois and important to them both. The house, the au pair, their whole standard of living depended on two salaries. And now what they were precariously achieving could be destroyed by that self-righteous, interfering Venetia.

I chose this place to live because I thought I would find anonymity. But it was not to be. People in the shops started to recognize me. The roses in my neighbor's garden were once loved. Usually, I stay inside, but tonight, I am watching the swifts flying. I have cut back rosemary and lemon balm to make a space for a chair. It is a narrow London garden. My upstairs neighbor, Jaz, is leaning out of the window. She is a writer. I have a copy of her latest manuscript. We talk for a while. I like her title and tell her so. I give her some advice about her writing. She is not happy. But I don't mind. I have my own life. I go out sometimes and fly home again.

Heritage gives people and communities a sense of connection to the past. It is important for understanding and interpreting our individual and national futures. Heritage represents a fundamental desire for continuity. It affects everything from customs to material culture.
Places and architectural 'memories' give us clues to our past. It is vitally important to conserve and restore these links as a testament to our ancestors' identity.
Museums exist to facilitate an encounter with authenticity. They present items that actually existed - were used - had meaning - at some historical time.
Architecture and Environment
The desire to preserve things is not new. Change in our towns comes with such speed and on such a scale that most of us are affected by it in some way. If there is a psychological need for preservation it is part of the planners job to take account of it.

Albert Einstein was a famous scientist who developed some mysterious theories about the universe. His theories are called relativity and are famous for being difficult to understand. Einstein made a big contribution to science by looking at the nature of time, space, matter and energy. He said that time and space are not absolute but relative.
Young Readers Lydia and I used to distrust prize-winning books because we thought they would be boring. Our father would give us money to read books and sometimes he would put a book in our presents that was not literature. But he did expose us to some shorter works of decent fiction and, just once, to a well-known anthology of verse.
Language is a mysterious and fascinating subject. It is difficult to understand the origin of language and how it has evolved over time. However, recent research has shed light on this topic. Language probably developed in East Africa, around 100,000 years ago. It was used for friendly interaction and power struggles.

Writing reviews is a skilled and multi-faceted job. It is one thing to write a short review for a newspaper, and quite another to write a long review for an international journal or a magazine. The reviewer needs to think about the probable audience, the length of the review, and the subject matter. They also need to know quite a bit about quite a number of things and be able to write prose that intelligent people can understand and enjoy.
However, reviewing is not a primary occupation. It is something you can only do well enough if you are also doing something else well enough.

Ralph unlocked the door to his flat and as he entered the dark, he felt a sense of ownership. When he first bought the flat, he used to come home feeling happy and relaxed. It had been a welcome to him, a place where he could focus and be himself. He had begun to regard it as another part of himself, a space where he could be alone and undisturbed. There was a small puddle of letters and a red eye of the answering machine that sometimes gathered by the door. And he was grateful that the glassy eyes of his windows hadn't been smashed. From the dreary distance of his office, Ralph often looked forward to his solitary evenings at home. He would read or listen to music as the night deepened outside. He felt lonely and powerless, but he knew that he was surviving.

I was going to witness goat racing on Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There was a lot of people and things around me, but I managed to get a good spot. The racecourse was not very big, but it was similar to other racecourses. The goats were being kept in order. They are very strong animals that can eat almost anything.
As the day was ending, I started to think about the night ahead. There was no place to sleep and we hadn't seen any villages or huts since early morning. It was dark and we couldn't see very well. We put in new batteries for our torch, but they didn't work. We couldn't find a place to camp. But then, we saw a flickering light and our hopes went up. It was the moonlight reflecting on the waves. We heard the sound of the water rushing past us, but we couldn't see what was happening. Time stood still and we moved on.

There are some activities that take a long time to complete. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient and add the oil too quickly, the mayonnaise curdles. If you start tugging with frustration on a tangled fishing line, the knot just becomes tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some of its functions are performed very quickly, while others take much longer. Some can be speeded up, but others cannot. If you try to rush a task, it will probably break down.
There are also different ways to think. Some people think quickly and make decisions based on their thoughts. Others think more slowly and carefully. There is no right or wrong way to think. The most important thing is to be able to think clearly and solve problems.

I have been welcomed warmly to this foreign land. It's a friendly and well-equipped base camp in a very remote place. There are a lot of people living there, mostly scientists, students, and weathermen. My school French is good enough to communicate, but not to chat or have fun. I miss the subtleties, and my phrasebook is useless at breakfast. There is no problem for me in this, but there was a problem of self-confidence. I felt a little nervous at mealtimes. I would hang back, worried about which table to choose and the silence that fell when I spoke. I still smile stupidly, or panic when people talk to me. I think the cause of this occasional depression is because I've lost the social confidence which my own gift of the gab has always afforded me.
When I first met Elliot, I was young and I didn't know him very well. But I ran into him here and there and he shook hands with me. From then on, since I had become successful, I began to see him more frequently.
Alfred Hitchcock was a film director who believed that the most important thing about his films was the photography and the soundtrack. He didn't care about the subject matter or the acting. Therefore, if a picture is designed correctly, the audience should react the same way, regardless of their cultural background.

Amateur Astronomy
Many things have changed in astronomy over the past fifty years. In the past, there were few charts and catalogues, and telescopic equipment was limited. Today, there are many more charts and catalogues, and telescopes are more accessible. Computers have made it easier to produce charts and analyze observations. All this makes this a good time for amateur astronomy.
However, there has also been a loss of things. The skies are now polluted by aircraft condensation trails, which can make it difficult to see stars. The daytime skies are also plagued by these trails, which can make it difficult to see the sun.
Society is also becoming more complex. There are too many choices, and this can be stressful. People are spending more time choosing what to do, and less time doing it. This is leading to a new trend: the search for "simplexity."
McAndrews Hotel
Every summer, we spend a fortnight in McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition that has been going on for many years. Nothing is allowed to interfere with the ritual. We are of a kind, McAndrews clientele: old-fashioned, odd perhaps, some would say snobbish. I do not like the bad manners, the insolence of shop assistants, and the chummy overtures from waiters. I know most of my fellow-guests' names, yet I can rest assured that when I meet any of them in any part of the hotel, I shall be spared all social intercourse apart from a civil word of greeting.

Othello, a play by Shakespeare, was recently transferred to London from Stratford. The production is exceptional and allows me to make amends for an unfair review I wrote last spring. I complained that the actor Ray Fearon was too young to play the title role, but I think it's a distortion of the tragedy to remove the age difference between Othello and Desdemona. However, I appreciate Mr Fearon's magnificent performance. The whole cast is magnificent, and there are many memorable scenes in the play.
Lake Vostok is a hidden freshwater lake in Antarctica. It is covered by a thick layer of ice and has been isolated from air and sunlight for millions of years. Scientists are excited to explore Lake Vostok and discover what strange organisms live there.
Scientists were talking on the radio about why they become scientists. They said that it is because of their desire to understand everything from the atom to the black hole. But they also said that it is more important to know whether what scientists are doing is right, rather than get bogged down in debates over the point of it all.

There is a special connection between people and food. Cooking is a satisfying and rewarding experience that can bring joy to both adults and children. It is also a way to share our creativity and love. When we cook, we are offering our own creations to others. Sharing food is a powerful symbol of our deepest human needs and it is often the centerpiece of our celebrations.
This morning, Alistair had a lot of paperwork to deal with. He had a lot of tax forms and other paperwork to file. He also had a lot of books and journals to organize. As he rode the elevator, he knew that his girlfriend, Mallory, would be on time for their appointment. She is very organized and she is always on time.
Karen had a desire not to be like her mother. She created her own story and mythology. In her story, there were significant moments in her progress. One day, she was hit in the eye by a golf club. But she was saved by the bone in her eye. She knew that she was saved for some purpose.
Miss Fogerty was excited and saddened by the scene she had just witnessed. She was excited to be the first to know something of note, but she was also saddened by the doctor's condition. The doctor has been her doctor for many years and she remembered with gratitude his concern for her annual bouts of laryngitis.

Joanna MacGregor is a concert pianist who has a busy schedule. She has added the task of writing books for young children learning the piano. Even though she is very busy, MacGregor still finds time to help young children learn the piano.
She has published her own elementary piano tutor for children called Joanna MacGregor's Piano World. She has managed to write the book despite her busy schedule. MacGregor is rare among top-flight concert pianists for her interest in how young children learn the piano.
She believes that everyone should be able to learn the piano, regardless of their ability level. She also believes that practice is the most important factor in learning the piano.

Writing and Reading
Dr Johnson believed that writing without effort is generally read without pleasure. Good writing comes hard. Looking back at my handwritten school essays, I was surprised at how few crossings-out they contained. Today I would have rewritten them five times over. The reason was that they were physically hard to write. The slowness of the hand disciplined the brain. What would be difficult to alter or erase was written with care.
Books versus Electronic Text
Reading anything lengthy on a screen is such a miserable experience that most never do it. The organisation of what resides in computers encourages people to dip into text. What is new is not so much the branchings of electronic text as that computers don't invite the joined-up thinking of reading anything in its entirety.
The Office
Charles walked through the office door and into a perfect world of order. The carpet was clear of the paper avalanche which had buried it on the very day it was put down, and the naked desk was dark wood, just as he remembered it from the Sotheby's auction of five weeks ago. He was admiring the room, its antique furniture. He was not visualising a computer or any other mechanical device in it, not even a pencil sharpener.

You don't take sugar, do you? The secretary shouted this as a fact. She had been making coffee for many months. She forgot to give him the coffee because she thought he wasn't supposed to be there. But nowadays he was always there. He had discovered that if he didn't take up his privilege of staying away, he would have to open the floodgates. The secretary gave him a folder with a book label. The book label said: 'A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert.' She also gave him a synopsis of the book. Lancelot did not want to see the synopsis. He had already seen a synopsis of this book and did not really want to see another. The book was not finished yet. It was going to take a long time to finish. The secretary remembered a famous author who had written a book that was never finished. But she thought that Ian's book would be finished eventually.

**
In England, breakfast is a relatively new tradition. It is not often described in medieval literature. There are some references to people having a meal at dawn or for medicinal reasons, but most people did not have breakfast unless they were royalty or wealthy. However, in the sixteenth century, breakfast became more common. This is probably because there was more food available. Also, new patterns of employment may have influenced the importance of breakfast. Many people started working very early, so they needed to have a meal first thing in the morning. Therefore, breakfast became more important for practical reasons than for social reasons.

When a photographer takes a photograph, they choose visual information that is determined by their technical and aesthetic skills, personal views and experience, and cultural norms. These factors affect the style, content and expression of a photograph. The viewer can question whether the photograph accurately recorded the scene or communicates the photographer's point of view.
Sport has taught me personal discipline and determination, but it can also teach you the benefits of working as one of a team. It's very much like life - you can succeed as an individual, but you must never forget there are others around you.
Some experiences etch themselves so sharply on our memory that they form islands of clarity in our recollection. For me, such a momentous occasion took place one night in California many years ago, when I lay awake listening to the beautiful sounds of a mockingbird singing. The bird had me convinced that I was being treated to an ad lib performance of the most breathtaking improvisational acrobatics.

Love them, fear them, worship them, human culture has always had a lot to say about birds. Birds have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people used to read the directions in which wrens flew to determine their luck. Today, the image of the wren is still in pictures and ceramics in many British households.
Birds are also important to us because they are indicators of environmental change. Conservationists in Britain cite the endangering of 30 species, which is a big loss of cultural heritage. Folklore is important because it can help us to understand and appreciate birds. The stories, legends and rhymes which persist through time can summon up feelings and attitudes from a consciousness buried under all the stuff of modern life.

A map is used to show the relationships between points and features on the Earth's surface. It is determined by distance and direction. In the past, distance was often measured in units of time, but such measurements gave more information about the relative ease of crossing the local terrains than about actual distance. Direction is also an important element of a map. The traveller's main concern was 'Where do I go from here?' and 'How far away is it?', so accurate representation of direction was not of primary importance. Early maps were often rivalled by written itineraries. Today, certain types of maps, such as those showing railway systems, may make little attempt to show true directions. Landmarks along a route were at first indicated by signs, realistic or conventional, and varied in size to indicate their importance. The history of cartography is largely that of the increase in the accuracy with which distance and direction are determined and the comprehensiveness of the map content. Today, cartography is used in many sciences, such as geology, history, and geography. It is also used to show distributions of various things, such as geological strata and climatic regimes.

I was invited to a young man's drawing room, which was like an oasis of cultured sanity. There was a large collection of records and a stereo record player and tuner. The young man's name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Oxford to read history. He had a lot of talent and was determined to become a composer. I was also ambitious and wanted to be a pop star. We had similar dreams, but my dreams were not life or death to me. When Andrew suggested a new ambition for me, I agreed to give it a go. He was a good musician and I could tell that he was going to be successful. We wrote a song together and I was proud of it. We parted ways, promising to meet again and to write something together. I was still interested in the charts than in the West End theatre, but I knew that I had just met somebody of rare ability and determination. I would continue to keep an eye out for opportunities to write music and would turn out a few more songs.

Language is a powerful tool that humans have. We can use language to communicate with each other and ourselves. It is such an instinctive skill that people know how to talk like spiders know how to spin webs. Climate and weather are also powerful forces that affect the lives of animals and plants. They can be a dominating force on the character of landscapes. For example, warm and wet climates allow the growth of tropical jungles, which are natural treasure troves. Cold, windswept areas can only muster a scattered selection of living things. The daily weather patterns that add up in the long term to the climate are caused by great masses of air rising and mixing. Some of the motion is due to the fact that the air rests on a spinning globe. A more important source of turbulence, or air movement, however, is the sun. Coffee is a popular drink that people enjoy all over the world. Making a good cup of coffee is not easy, but it is an art and a science. By the end of the first week, I had to admit that making a decent cup of coffee was not as easy as it looked.

Art on TV is not very successful at showing paintings and sculptures. It could be because the camera does not always have the ability to show the details of a work of art. There are few series on television that have managed to convey both the pleasure and complexity of looking at paintings and sculptures.
A good example of what goes wrong can be seen in Robert Hughes's eight-part survey of American art, American Visions. Hughes is a critic you can trust. He has a personality that commands attention and he has been given nearly eight hours in which to introduce British audiences to a school of art that British galleries have totally ignored. I had expected the series to focus on great works of art. What I got instead was one about the way American history and culture are reflected in its art and architecture.
Dealing in Metals is a risky business. It is regulated far less than other markets. With a bit of luck, a willingness to take a risk and a good understanding of how the market works, it's possible to make a lot of money. But now the free-trade economists who claimed the market itself would maintain the price of scarce metals have found the opposite is happening. More minerals are being extracted and the cost of raw materials is decreasing. Taking inflation into account, the prices of most metals are about half of what they were 20 years ago.
Abaco and its off-shore cays are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas. It is a beautiful place with a lot to offer. If you want to get anywhere in Abaco, you need a boat. There are plenty of boats to rent or you can sail. Abaco is nicknamed 'The Sailing Capital of the World' for good reason. It is a paradise for fishing, diving, snorkelling and swimming.

The Bamboo Bike Club offers a course where you can build your own bike. It's a fun weekend of bike-building in Hackney Wick, east London. You'll learn how to select bamboo for strength, form strong joints, and assemble the frame. You can also choose the color of your frame and add your personal touches. The course is perfect for engineers and anyone else who wants to build a unique and sustainable bike.
The cost of the course is less than PS500. You'll also get to ride your bike on the road. The ride is light, stiff and smooth thanks to bamboo's ability to dampen vibration.

Self-help books are popular in America. There is a big industry for self-help books. Many people write self-help books. Some books are very successful. One popular book is about how to bridge communication gaps between the sexes. It is a bestseller.
There are a lot of reasons why people write self-help books. Some people want to help others. Some people want to make money. Some people want to share their own experiences. There are also some people who write self-help books because they want to be famous.
Writing a self-help book can be a lot of work. It takes a lot of time and effort. But if you are passionate about helping others, it can also be a very rewarding experience.

Air-conditioning is used a lot at Cannons Gym, a popular place for workers in the City of London. It is very hot this summer, so the gym has gone overboard with the air-conditioning. Sometimes, the gym feels like a place in the Arctic. Air-conditioning is used a lot in many buildings, but there are other ways to cool them down. For example, buildings could use more natural light and ventilation, and thicker walls that absorb heat during the day and radiate it away at night. These measures would reduce the need for air-conditioning.
Sundials are instruments used to measure time. They were once a vital time-keeping device, but now they are mostly used as garden ornaments. People are starting to use sundials again because they are becoming more interested in the stars and planets.
Paint Your Own China is a course where people can learn to paint china-painting. The course is not difficult, and it is a lot of fun. The students are all there to have fun, and they do not worry about making mistakes.

The Wrong Country Uncle chose a package holiday for them at a very reasonable price. When Keith and Dawne went to make the booking, the counter clerk explained that the other members of that particular package were a school group from the south coast, all of them learning Italian. But something went wrong. They ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, somewhere in Switzerland.
When they arrived at the hotel, they were greeted by a woman who introduced herself as Mrs. Franks. She explained that they had been booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. But when they realized that they were in the wrong country, they became alarmed. They tried to explain their situation to the receptionist, but he did not understand. They were frustrated and tired, so they decided to just go with it.
The next morning, they found out that they were being offered beds for the duration of their holiday. They were concerned about the mistake, but they eventually accepted the offer. They spent the rest of their holiday enjoying the lakeside air and the company of the elderly people.

Ernest Shackleton was an American executive who was adopted as a model of good management. Most people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and have a rough idea of what he did. America has only just discovered him. Now the Americans are making up for lost time with powerful enthusiasm. They are producing biographies and accounts of Shackleton's voyage, mounting a grand exhibition, and preparing a film based on his life. Some American managers have also adopted Shackleton as an icon and exemplar. His leadership and communication skills are being taught to others.
Shackleton was a determined and resourceful person. He had a reindeer sleeping bag and a blubber-stove. He was at his best when he and those dependent on him had a great deal to lose. One of the most fascinating decisions Shackleton made was to turn back when only 97 miles from the South Pole. He was prepared to stand up and accept responsibility.
Shackleton believed that an explorer needs optimism, physical endurance and patience. He taught others that if you buy bonds and guess wrong on the interest rates, you hang in there and eventually you'll get your money back. If a new product's a stinker, don't keep selling it.
